content.question: A sample of an ideal gas in a sealed container occupies a volume of <math alttext="50.0 liters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>50.0</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math> at <math alttext="200 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>200</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>. The temperature of the gas is changed to <math alttext="400 kelvin" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>400</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mi mathvariant="normal">K</mi></math>, and the pressure doubles. Which of the following must occur and why?

choices.label: Volume must decrease because the pressure is higher.
Volume must increase because the temperature is higher.
Volume must remain the same because the pressure and temperature change proportionately.
Volume cannot be predicted without knowing the number of moles of gas in the sample.

content.answer: Volume must remain the same because the pressure and temperature change proportionately.
